description.narrative: The National port and freight study study addresses the current challenges faced by the regional economies of Mozambique and hinterland countries (mainly: Zimbabwe, Malawi, Zambia and eSwatini), that demand efficient transport services for goods and services for key economic sectors in the country, such as the agri-food & nutrition and the extractive sector. The results of the project provide a clear pathway to empower the role of the current Mozambican ports, in particular through the main corridors: Maputo, Beira and Nacala. The project also identifies opportunities to increase competitiveness of the Mozambican transport corridors, which in turn would improve the competitive position of the Mozambican ports and thus increase cargo volumes and corresponding economic growth and employment opportunities. Besides, the study also defines opportunities to improve the cabotage system that will enable efficient North-South transport of cargo and passengers along the Mozambican coast. This would especially be beneficial for coastal communities away from one of the main seaports (Maputo, Beira, Nacala and Pemba). These communities often face issues such as a lack of market access, low availability of goods, high transport costs and corresponding prices. The results of the study summarize the assessment of Mozambique’s port and maritime sector and provides a strategic vision for the development of the sector. This analysis has been undertaken by Royal HaskoningDHV on behalf of The Dutch government for the Mozambican Ministry of Transport and Communication to support development of the maritime sector.The National port and freight study study addresses the current challenges faced by the regional economies of Mozambique and hinterland countries (mainly: Zimbabwe, Malawi, Zambia and eSwatini), that demand efficient transport services for goods and services for key economic sectors in the country, such as the agri-food & nutrition and the extractive sector. The results of the project provide a clear pathway to empower the role of the current Mozambican ports, in particular through the main corridors: Maputo, Beira and Nacala. The project also identifies opportunities to increase competitiveness of the Mozambican transport corridors, which in turn would improve the competitive position of the Mozambican ports and thus increase cargo volumes and corresponding economic growth and employment opportunities. Business development, by investment or trade of local or Dutch companies with(in) low and middle income countries

title.narrative: Number of people directly reached - Total

comment.narrative:
Dutch and Local The following entities have been involved in the study, in varying levels of involvement. Some of them have been an integral part in the project team including participation in site visits and stakeholder meetings, whereas others have only been consulted on a high level. In alphabetical order:
1. Associação das Linhas de Navegação (ALN) 2. Associação dos Transportadores Rodoviário de Carga de Sofala (ASTROS) 3. Beira Municipality (CMB) 4. Belgium Development Agency (ENABEL) 5. Caminhos de Ferroviarios de Moçambique (CFM) 6. Cornelder de Moçambique 7. Corredor de Desenvolvimento de Norte (CDN) 8. DP World 9. Escola Nautica 10. European Union 11. International Finance Cooperation (IFC) 12. MANICA 13. Maputo Port Development Company (MPDC) 14. MCNet 15. Mozambican Ministry of Economics and Finance (Customs) 16. Mozambican Ministry of Industry and Commerce 17. Mozambican Ministry of Transport and Communications (MTC) 18. MSC 19. Nacala Logistics 20. Netherlands Enterprise Agency (RVO.nl) 21. Port of Antwerp 22. Port of Rotterdam 23. Portos de Norte 24. Sociedade de Desenvolvimento da Beira (SDUB) 25. Sociedade Moçambicana de Cabotagem 26. STC International 27. Terminais de Norte 28. USAID

title.narrative: Number of identified opportunities for investment and/or follow-up PSD projects - Total

comment.narrative:
Final report including comments and suggestions from Clients and stakeholders, with executive summary and corresponding presentation in English and Portuguese. This report includes is structured in three main components: Merchant Navy, Development of National ports and Freight Study Result is an strategic plan on the development of the national port and maritime sector including: o Vision, Main Objectives and anticipated Results of the strategic plan o Four main pillars for implementation: 1) Collaboration, 2) Digitization, 3) Capacity building and 4) Physical Infrastructure o Description of each of the pillars including an elaboration of underlying programs and Priority Actions
The following opportunities for investement were identified per pillar: • 12 priority Actions that are part of Pillar 1 – Collaboration that support development of port and maritime sector • 8 priority Actions that are part of Pillar 2 – Digitization that will support Freight and efficiency of supply chain logistics. • 8 priority Actions that are part of Pillar 3 –Capacity Building that support development of skills in the port and maritime sector • 5 priority Actions that are part of Pillar 4 – Physical (Port) Infrastructure Development.

title.narrative: Increased impact of an existing PSD project

comment.narrative: The study builds further on the following PSD projects: - Project MAT17MZ06 Inception study port of Mocimboa de Praia, and - Project MAT18MZ01 Scoping Study Upgrading Angoche Harbour - Projects EKN17MZ01, EKN17MZ02, EKN17MZ03T: echnical support to programmatic deployment in the Netherlands - Mozambique with focus on Beira. - Project MAK14MZ01 Regional Offshore Training Center aiming at skill development of domestic maritime sector.

title.narrative: Description of changes achieved in laws, regulations, policy plans, outcomes of social dialogue or development strategies enacted or adopted by local government or social dialogue partners, yielding tangible benefits to the business climate

comment.narrative: Development of the Merchant Navy The consultant shall submit a preliminary report to the Ministry of Transport and Communications and to the selected stakeholders detailing all the activities described for the second phase: “Development of the Merchant Navy”.

Draft study report submitted with the following specific content related to the development of the Merchant Navy:
• Description of historic and existing coastal trade services in Mozambique • Analysis of the complexity of the cabotage supply chain and bottlenecks for further development including road as a competing transport mode. • Assessment of the legislative and regulatory framework related to the maritime and shipping industry in Mozambique with a focus on the development of national shipping services and merchant navy. • Overview and recommendations with regards to the increase of local content in cabotage and international maritime trade.
Technical input for improvement of existing rcabotage and merchant navy regulations: • SWOT analysis with 20 elements to improve cabotage and domestic Merchant Navy • Inclusion of private sector comments and considerations to improve business climate and specially supply chain efficiency • Inclusion of cabotage company comments to improve feasibility of operations, thereby improve potential for domestic merchant navy development

title.narrative: Number of members of supported organisations - Total

comment.narrative:
The results of the study summarize the assessment of Mozambique’s port and maritime sector and provides a strategic vision for the development of the sector. This analysis has been undertaken by Royal HaskoningDHV on behalf of The Dutch government for the Mozambican Ministry of Transport and Communication to support development of the maritime sector. 3 staff members from CFM (national port and rail authority of Mozambique) have been included in the project team and participated in the main study activities> e.g. site visits, meetings with stakeholders
The study identified six key points to better position and develop the maritime transport of Mozambique. It provides concrete and pragmatic recommendations for the definition of: a) Provision of efficient transport corridors to serve the domestic market and hinterland countries such as Zimbabwe, Malawi, Zambia and eSwatini. b) Establish a cabotage trade network with secondary ports as a ‘coastal highway’. c) Ensure a flexible and robust future development strategy for Northern Cabo Delgado. d) Create a vision on Inland Waterway Transport and related inland port development. e) Maintain proper educational / skill training opportunities for Mozambican staff. f) Ensure the maritime sector develops in a sustainable way in harmony with society and environment.
